The thing about permanent bans is just that. They're permanent. They're meant to be dreaded. If they ever backtracked on permabans (sans ones made in error), the fear of such things happening would lose its edge.

No. Once an account is validly permabanned it is gone for good, and not even pros or popular streamers have gotten any of their permabanned accounts back. Why? Because there has to be some lasting penalty and reminder that actions have consequences. From the [Tribunal FAQ](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=2411284): 

>**Why can’t you give permanent banned players a second chance? You will receive a better player. **
Actually, this is the unfortunate problem. Allowing permanently banned players another chance is an extremely damaging cost. Do you know what the success rate of the Level 20 Challenge was? 5%. Do you know that for each person, they clearly outlined the toxic behaviors and had 1 on 1 conversations with the players to try to improve their behavior? These are players that were hand-picked by Player Support staff because they felt the pleas from these players were genuine. The success rate was still 5%. 

>Do you know how many games on average these players played? 100 games / month. When a permanently banned player fails to reform, they are creating miserable experiences for hundreds, maybe thousands of players a month. That's not a cheap cost or a low risk and we cannot consciously justify that, for the sake of the rest of our players.

These days players have at least 3 chances to reform (1 if given a 14-day ban for a zero-tolerance policy violation) before being permabanned, with the possibility of more if a player is able to improve their behavior before reaching that point. If that's not enough then Riot doesn't want you playing anymore. That said, Riot can't stop people from making new accounts, so if you truly want to prove you're reformed then do so on your other account. Oh, and before you or someone else tries to bring the money argument into this, to quote [Kei143](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/mmh6PidR-the-dreaded-downvoteers-in-this-discussion-board?comment=0001000100000000000100000004): 

>When Riot permabans someone, their philosophy is "the chances of this guy reforming isn't a whole lot, we'd rather not have him in the game". Thus in their eyes, they have already written off the toxic player as a paying client.

>From a business standpoint, do they want to remove the toxic guy who has spent $500 but is causing a negative environment for 4-9 other players in every game? Those non-toxics are also spending $500 and probably will spend more, promote the game more when they are enjoying the game AND they won't cause a negative environment.

>I personally think it is a fine argument to protect the ones that are paying money and aren't toxic rather than protecting the ones that may pay the same amount but are toxic.
Who cares about popular streamers? They make enough money from streaming to rebuild an account. But regular players can't afford to lose all the items they spent money on. Logic.

> [{quoted}](name=KazukaoO,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=nzZocANO,comment-id=00060001,timestamp=2019-04-05T02:05:56.336+0000)
>
> But what was the thing about tyler1? didnt he got enough perma bans and at the end also a IP ban? what was the reason he got "free" again?

Not IP, [ID-a ban on sight type of ban](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/115013815928-Understanding-ID-Bans) where any accounts that were confirmed to be by him were immediately permabanned on the spot. Only the ID ban was lifted after he had waited a year after receiving it and after proving to Riot that he had reformed enough to warrant it being lifted. All of his permabanned accounts remain that way to this day.

Ever? Maybe in the far future.

Current policy and near future? No.

There is a method in which you can prove yourself to be reformed

but you need a long period of evidence and you need clean records on whatever your other account is

There is no such method for the people who have been permanently suspended. You might be thinking of the old system that Riot had in place at some point in the past, but it has not existed in a long while anymore - and for a good reason. You can find more information about the current situation and the reasons why that previous system does not exist anymore from this thread, so I don't go into details about those.

Anyways as an answer to OP's question/poll; No, they won't unban the permanently suspended accounts. And good thing that they don't. What kind of 'permanent suspension' would that be if it wasn't permanent?

your right , and i agree with you on that , but wahts the point of having perma bans? people play  the game , buy iingame items , and then you just had a bad day , and you come to enjoy the game itself , and you get trolls feeders etc , me who flames get the suspencion , and the others what do they recieve? nothing because it was me who was ruining the game , and there it goes the money you've spent the time and  the effort down the drain

I guess one of the possible points is, that since people know about the threat of losing their account permanently, it reduces the amount of trolling/griefing done, especially if the person has invested money on the account. I think that is the main reason for having permanent bans. 

What alternative would there be for permanent suspensions? If the worst was just 14-day suspension, it would mean that soon the trolls would have couple of accounts, which they alternate while the other(s) are on that 14-day cooldown. Or if the punishment increased every time by for example extra week, it would soon in practice be permanent suspension. 

Permanent suspensions are fine. People should learn to behave or leave. If you respond to trolling, you are feeding them. Learn to Mute & Report like the rest of the rational people.
